field_edited_text.value:
74 Patarsco RivEr CROSSING

lower the height of the top of the bridge towers. Design details of the
cantilever unit are shown on Plates 38 to 42 inclusive. The main canti-
lever span is supported on battered tower bents over piers Numbers 7 and
8. These towers are 144 feet in height and are spread 89 feet transversly
and 38 feet longitudinally at their base. The two tower legs are composed
of three sections. The straight center section is designed to carry the super-
imposed load and the two curved outside legs come into action to overcome
the effect of longitudinal forces on the bridge. Design details of the canti-
lever span towers are shown on Plate 43. All expansion due to temperature in
the main span between pier 7 and pier 8 is taken by an expansion joint placed
at one end of the suspended span. The other end of the suspended span
being pinned directly to the cantilever arm. The ends of the anchor arms
are carried on split flexible bents over piers Numbers 6 and 9. At this
point the expansion in the roadway takes place for the entire distance be-
tween piers Numbers 5 and 7, and 8 and 10.

The roadway for the entire main bridge and approaches is 46 feet wide
between curbs and consists of a steel grid type floor filled with concrete and
with a 3/4 inch concrete overfill. Integral colored concrete traffic lines
will be placed monolithically with the concrete wearing surface. The curbs
and 1 foot 6 inch walkways on either side of the roadway are made of steel
plates supported on diaphragms. The roadway slab on the main bridge is
supported on steel cross beams which rest on the longitudinal stringers.
On the approach spans the roadway slab rests directly upon the floor beams,
stringers and brackets. The railing on the main bridge consists of channels
supported by steel posts fastened to each cross beam. On the approach
spans the railing is a solid plate girder type stiffened with longitudinal
angles and spanning from post to post over the brackets about 23 feet
center to center.

The bridge and approaches will be lighted by high efficiency lights placed
on poles and at sufficient height above the roadway to prevent glare and
yet flood the roadway with a uniform light throughout.

BRIDGE ROADWAY

The roadway for this bridge consists of an open mesh type flooring filled
with concrete, which when completed will present the appearance of a
concrete roadway surface. The weight of the floor in the design of the
bridge includes an allowance for the future addition of two inches of asphalt
or other wearing surface.
